importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking when the UN World Meteorological Organization released its report on global disaster alerts and early-warning systems amid rising extreme weather events.

The date of a specific glacier collapse in Switzerland, which prompted the evacuation of the village of Blatten, demonstrating real-world impact of early warning systems and the urgency of climate monitoring.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The global surge in weather-related disasters in 2025, including flooding in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, underscores the urgency of early-warning systems in the current climate crisis.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable to disaster-related deaths.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems; 90% of past 50 years' weather-related fatalities occurred in developing countries.

Over the last decade, the number of countries with multi-hazard early warning systems has increased from 52 to at least 108, but still, 50% of assessed countries have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most critical in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being observed in Africa, where more countries now have functioning alert websites and standardized early warnings.
Early warnings enable early action and are essential to saving lives and protecting infrastructure as extreme weather events intensify due to climate change.
The WMO's goal is not just to issue warnings, but to empower communities and nations to respond effectively.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN’s World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has issued a global call to action for strengthening early-warning systems against extreme weather events, emphasizing that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capacity. With over 2 million people dying from weather-related disasters in the past 50 years—90% in developing nations—climate change is intensifying risks. Despite progress in early-warning adoption, 50% of 62 assessed countries still have only basic systems. The WMO highlights that fragile and conflict-affected regions face the greatest vulnerability, while progress is seen in Africa. Real-world examples, such as the evacuation of Blatten, Switzerland, after a glacier collapse in May 2025, demonstrate the life-saving potential of early warnings. The organization stresses that early warnings are not just alerts but tools for empowering communities to take proactive action, especially as extreme weather events spiral due to climate change.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
